575. Rathwell Isabella (Mrs. John Garfield)
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. It is better to leave details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Days: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered it, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here.

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaire conditions

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Rathwell, Isabella (Mrs. J.G.)
630 Minico St., Moose Jaw.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE
No. 2
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE
A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life, because no individual who has lived through it can possibly give the same experiences as another. Some of the questions may not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If these spaces are left there is not sufficient space to answer the questions in full. Write to explain, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:
Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Days: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Say?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here.

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark those you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaire conditions

- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and furnishings
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Rathwell
2. Your address: 630 Main St., Moose Jaw
3. Date: July 1, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) On my father's farm.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   Born here in 1897, mulets.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

Have lived in Saskatchewan all my life.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child.")

"I was in my teens," etc.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

All of my fellow people eventually came west and settled North west of Moose Jaw.

What later became known as Athabasca district—His father and mother, four brothers and three sisters were at one time settled very close to each other.
Rathwell, Isabella (Mrs. J.G.)
351 Main St., Moose Jaw

II. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Work at good rates of pay were available.

So we went by ourselves or with a party (family, friends or other groups).

In the summer of 1936 we moved to Kindersley, Saskatchewan.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Work at good value of land was available.

So, they thought we should go.

12. How did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

In the summer by train in normal cars and went away after rain into the mountains.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

On B.C. H. W. work on the bridges and bridge builders and I have heard him talk thrillingly about the Peace River and other places.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way?)

Meetings with Indians' adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences.

15. What happened to the people and my mother's cattle?

Cattle by the same railroad, carrying cattle east and west.

To come from Strathcona County in April-May to help my father in the time of need.

Father helped me work on the right of way. He was able to build the fence each year.

My life came above, until the fall of 1936 when he left home and his mother could not find him.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

I came to Saskatchewan.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

My husband and I moved to Kindersley, then to Prince Albert, and we moved to Kindersley at Tolovana.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live, and occupations.

We have our children, as given in my journal.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The earlier unhampered life seems to be gone,
and despite all the modern improvements,
we live a harsher more hurried life.

Partly because farms are in bigger units,
and farm life does not attract the younger people.
